item.title: Customer Analysis Part 2
item.description:
• Part 1
  • Libaries and Data
  • RFM Analysis
  • Clustering
    • Set Up
    • Final Model
    • Cluster Profiles
  • Wrap Up

Part 1

This is a continuation of a previous post. If you haven’t already, give it a read here. We take an exploratory data analysis approach with a data set from a retailer/wholesaler from the UK. In that post we looked at dollar drivers, unit drivers and where sales were originating from. This will examine clusters of customers, trying to identify which customers are similar.

Libaries and Data

Let’s load in our data and our libraries. We can find our sales csv in my github.

library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)
library(lubridate)
library(rfm)

sales <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/BrettMoxham/Random-Projects/master/Consumer%20Data%20-%20EDA/sales.csv")

RFM Analysis

RFM analysis, is a great way to compare and contrast customers. RFM stands for Recency Frequency Monetary. We want to see how recently a customer has purchased from us, how often they do so, and how much they spend. Those 3 metrics can then be used to cluster our customers together into groups. We can then extrapolate the groupings into a customer profile, and we can use these customer profiles to help group other customers into those profiles as well. These profiles can be used with things such as target marketing, so that we can tailor our marketing approach to each individual customer. Let’s run some RFM analysis on our sales data. However, we still need to clean our data even further. We are going to use the rfm package for our analysis. We need:

  • The number of orders per customer
  • Number of days since last transaction
  • Date of the analysis (for this we will use January 1st 2012, as this data covers 2010/2011)
  • Total revenue by customer
sales_rfm <- sales %>% 
  group_by(customer_id) %>% 
  summarise(
    num_trans = n_distinct(invoice_no),
    num_days = as.Date("2012/01/01") - max(date),
    total_revenue = sum(item_value)
            ) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  filter(!is.na(customer_id))

rfm_table <- rfm_table_customer(sales_rfm, 
                   customer_id = "customer_id",
                   n_transactions = "num_trans",
                   recency_days = "num_days",
                   total_revenue = "total_revenue",
                   analysis_date = as.Date("2012/01/01")
                   )
knitr::kable(head(rfm_table$rfm))
customer_id recency_days transaction_count amount recency_score frequency_score monetary_score rfm_score
12346 348 days 2 0.00 1 2 1 121
12347 25 days 7 4310.00 5 4 5 545
12348 98 days 4 1797.24 2 3 4 234
12349 41 days 1 1757.55 4 1 4 414
12350 333 days 1 334.40 1 1 2 112
12352 59 days 11 1545.41 3 5 4 354

We now have a table outlining our RFM data. Each customer is graded on a 1 - 5 scale, with 1 being least valuable and 5 being most. A customer who ranks as a 5,5,5 is our most valuable customer. They spend the most, are buying the most frequently and have bought recently. On the other side, a 1,1,1 customer is not valuable at all, and we should not waste time pursuing them for future sales. They buy small amounts infrequently and haven’t bought recently at all.

Let’s visualize our data here firstly.

rfm_fm_plot(rfm_table)

Our customers are clustered quite close together for the majority of customers. However we see a few who either spend quite a bit more than others, or who are sending in invoices quite often.

Clustering

We can use the K-Means algorithm to group our customers. K means is an unsupervised algorithm that takes \(k\) random centroids (these k points are in our data points already, and chosen at random). The centroids then define a cluster where in the remaining data points are assigned to their nearest centroid (1 and only 1 centroid) by euclidean distance. The centroids are then shifted such that the total euclidean distance is reduced for each cluster (some data points may change clusters in this shifting). This process repeats until there is no shift in centroids that will reduce the euclidean distance of their clusters anymore. The final shift will produce the final centroids and in turn the final clusters for the data.

Set Up

Firstly, we need to get our rfm scores only. Our current rfm_table has a bunch of extra data that we won’t use in our K-means algorithm.

rfm_scores <- rfm_table$rfm[,(5:7)]

knitr::kable(head(rfm_scores))
recency_score frequency_score monetary_score
1 2 1
5 4 5
2 3 4
4 1 4
1 1 2
3 5 4

Now we a data set with only our recency, frequency and monetary scores. Each is still representative of our customers, but we no longer need the customer_id value as we are only trying to get a sense of what each customer is. We can now run our K-means algorithm. Let’s arbitrarily use a k value equal to 5. This will create 5 clusters.

k_means_basic <- kmeans(rfm_scores, centers = 5)
head(k_means_basic$cluster)
## [1] 5 3 1 4 5 3

We’ve run our K-means algorithm and assigned each customer to a cluster. We’ve arbitrarily chosen 5 as our number of clusters, however this may not be the best number to chose. We need a way to determine the best number of clusters. We can do this by using a function, and iterating over a vector of k values.

k <- as.vector(2:20)
set.seed(123)

kmeans_function <- function(k){
  
  cluster <- kmeans(rfm_scores, centers = k)
  return(cluster$tot.withinss)
}

cluster_withinness <- sapply(k, kmeans_function)

cluster_df <- data.frame(k, cluster_withinness)

What we’ve done here is iterate through bunch of different k values and taken the sum of squares for each k value. We can graph our k values and our sum of squares to create an elbow plot. Where our elbow plot “bends” is our best fit value for k.

ggplot(cluster_df, aes(x = k, y = cluster_withinness)) +
  geom_point()+
  geom_line()+
  labs(
    title = "Which K Should We Use?",
    x = "K",
    y = "Sum of Squares"
  )+
  theme_light()

Final Model

It looks like this we have a elbow somewhere around 5 to 7. Let’s use 7 as our k value. We can now re-run our K-means algorithm to view our clusters and their centers.

set.seed(123)
k_means_final <- kmeans(rfm_scores, centers = 7)

k_means_final$centers
##   recency_score frequency_score monetary_score
## 1      4.471088        3.382653       3.700680
## 2      2.348162        3.725338       4.214700
## 3      1.473177        1.588721       2.698762
## 4      4.503277        4.847969       4.874181
## 5      4.385463        1.621145       1.894273
## 6      2.736726        2.803097       2.550885
## 7      1.846154        1.159587       1.216992

These are our clusters, with their cluster center values. Looking at the values, it seems like cluster 2 represents our best customers. They buy a lot, frequently and have bought most recently. Cluster 1 represents our worst customers. They don’t buy a often, haven’t bought lots, and the last time they bought was a while ago. Examining the remaining clusters we can build a profile of our clusters. For instance looking at cluster 6. They are a customer who’ve bought something for the first time recently, but just a small amount. Let’s see if we can identify a profile for our clusters.

Cluster Profiles

k_means_final$centers
##   recency_score frequency_score monetary_score
## 1      4.471088        3.382653       3.700680
## 2      2.348162        3.725338       4.214700
## 3      1.473177        1.588721       2.698762
## 4      4.503277        4.847969       4.874181
## 5      4.385463        1.621145       1.894273
## 6      2.736726        2.803097       2.550885
## 7      1.846154        1.159587       1.216992

Cluster Profiles:

  1. These customers buy somewhat frequently, however haven’t in some time. It may be worth to send them a contact to see if they are worth following up on.
  2. Our best customers - They a lot, frequently and have done so recently. Keep these guys happy!
  3. They buy a relatively large amount, in frequently and have done so recently. No real need to send them any incentives, as they are unlikely to buy right away.
  4. These are our 2nd best customers, They buy a lot, and frequently. It may be worth exploring incentives to see if you can convert them to the ranks of best customers.
  5. These are in the range of our 2nd best customers. They buy a lot and frequently, but haven’t bought in a while. It may be that they are moving away from our services. It would be worth while to touch base with these customers so that we can try and salvage them as customers.
  6. These are new customers. Ones who have bought recently but only a small amount and most likely for the first time. Targeted marketing may be worth while to help convert them to regular customers.
  7. These are dead customers. They don’t buy much, and haven’t done recently. We should move on from any marketing to these customers, as they are unlikely to be valuable to us.

Let’s add our cluster designations back into our original data, so that we can see which customer fits into which cluster.

customer_clusters <- augment(k_means_final, rfm_table$rfm) %>% 
  select(customer_id, .cluster)

sales_clustered <- sales_rfm %>% 
  left_join(customer_clusters, by = "customer_id")
head(sales_clustered) %>%
  knitr::kable()
customer_id num_trans num_days total_revenue .cluster
12346 2 348 days 0.00 7
12347 7 25 days 4310.00 4
12348 4 98 days 1797.24 2
12349 1 41 days 1757.55 5
12350 1 333 days 334.40 3
12352 11 59 days 1545.41 2

Now we can identify which customer belongs to which cluster. We can now identify which customers can use some marketing and which we can stop focusing on. For instance, customer 12346 is in cluster 7 and is a dead customer. If we are marketing towards them, we could allocate those dollars to other customers and see a larger return. Let’s identify our a few of our “new” customers. This would equate to cluster 6.

sales_clustered %>% 
  filter(.cluster == 6) %>% 
  head(15) %>% 
  knitr::kable()
customer_id num_trans num_days total_revenue .cluster
12371 2 67 days 1887.96 6
12379 3 104 days 850.29 6
12394 2 86 days 1272.48 6
12403 2 72 days 409.70 6
12413 5 89 days 694.15 6
12422 3 118 days 803.56 6
12434 4 107 days 765.19 6
12452 3 39 days 428.57 6
12458 2 94 days 947.40 6
12468 3 166 days 724.04 6
12492 2 86 days 263.21 6
12493 3 188 days 416.79 6
12498 3 44 days 403.70 6
12527 3 104 days 348.71 6
12552 2 61 days 437.82 6

As we can see, these customers have very few purchases and a relatively low total order value. But they also have bought recently. We can try some marketing towards these customers in order to convert them to a more valuable customer! Let’s take a look at our “faltering customers” in cluster 5.

sales_clustered %>% 
  filter(.cluster == 5) %>% 
  head(15) %>% 
  knitr::kable()
customer_id num_trans num_days total_revenue .cluster
12349 1 41 days 1757.55 5
12367 1 27 days 168.90 5
12374 1 48 days 742.93 5
12375 3 25 days 455.42 5
12391 1 44 days 460.89 5
12442 1 26 days 172.06 5
12445 1 45 days 133.40 5
12478 1 26 days 680.99 5
12504 4 41 days 114.00 5
12508 2 49 days 398.27 5
12531 1 37 days 125.22 5
12532 1 53 days 349.83 5
12538 1 52 days 363.95 5
12544 2 52 days 355.70 5
12558 2 24 days 0.00 5

We can see a stark difference between cluster 5 and 6. As we identified in our cluster portfolios, cluster 6 was our “new customers” and cluster 5 is our “almost 2nd best” customer. They are customers are who used to buy lots and frequently, how ever haven’t done so in a while. We can see this manifested when we view some of the customers who fall in this cluster. Customer 12352 has 11 separate transactions, however hasn’t bough in 59 days. Customer 12409 has 7 different transactions but hasn’t bought in 101 days! These customers are worth touching base with to see if we can re-ignite purchasing.

Wrap Up

We’ve run a combination of recency frequency monetary analysis and K-Means algorithms on our sales data. What we’ve worked out is a profile of our customers. We can use these profiles to better utilize our marketing efforts. For instance, if we identify a customer as one in cluster 7 of our profile, we would want to reduce or all out stop marketing towards them. More likely than not, that customer is dead weight. However if we identify a customer as being in cluster 5, we may want to touch base with them. These customers were once very good, however they have stop buying for one reason or another. We will, at least, want to monitor these customers in case they slip to a lower quality customer.

item.title: Customer Analysis - EDA
item.description:
library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate) #used to parse date and time in our data cleaning step.
library(gt)

Objective

Taking the data set provided by the UCI Machine Learning Repository, we want to take an exploratory data analysis approach to gain insights into this store’s customer. This data set contains transactions occurring between 01/12/2010 and 09/12/2011 for a UK-based and registered non-store online retail.The company mainly sells unique all-occasion gifts. Many customers of the company are wholesalers.

A few things that we want to look at:

  • Sales by day
  • Unit drivers
  • Dollar drivers
  • Orders/order value by country

Data

As stated above, we’ve taken data provided from the UCI Machine Learning Repository. You can find a link to the actual data here.

online_retail <-  readxl::read_xlsx("C:/Users/Brett/Desktop/Github/Random Projects/Consumer Data - EDA/Online Retail.xlsx") ##reads in our data

online_retail <- online_retail %>% ##converts character variables to factor
  mutate_if(is.character, as.factor) %>% 
  janitor::clean_names() ## cleans up variable names.

Data Cleaning

Let’s take a quick first look at our data so we can see what we are dealing with.

skimr::skim(online_retail)
Table 1: Data summary
Name online_retail
Number of rows 541909
Number of columns 8
_______________________
Column type frequency:
factor 4
numeric 3
POSIXct 1
________________________
Group variables None

Variable type: factor

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate ordered n_unique top_counts
invoice_no 0 1 FALSE 25900 573: 1114, 581: 749, 581: 731, 580: 721
stock_code 0 1 FALSE 4070 851: 2313, 224: 2203, 850: 2159, 475: 1727
description 1454 1 FALSE 4211 WHI: 2369, REG: 2200, JUM: 2159, PAR: 1727
country 0 1 FALSE 38 Uni: 495478, Ger: 9495, Fra: 8557, EIR: 8196

Variable type: numeric

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate mean sd p0 p25 p50 p75 p100 hist
quantity 0 1.00 9.55 218.08 -80995.00 1.00 3.00 10.00 80995 ▁▁▇▁▁
unit_price 0 1.00 4.61 96.76 -11062.06 1.25 2.08 4.13 38970 ▁▇▁▁▁
customer_id 135080 0.75 15287.69 1713.60 12346.00 13953.00 15152.00 16791.00 18287 ▇▇▇▇▇

Variable type: POSIXct

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate min max median n_unique
invoice_date 0 1 2010-12-01 08:26:00 2011-12-09 12:50:00 2011-07-19 17:17:00 23260

We have over 540,000 different orders, of which we have 8 different data points on each. We have data on:

  • The invoice number
  • The stock code
  • The stock description
  • Country of purchase
  • Quantity purchased
  • Unit price
  • Anonymized customer ID number
  • Invoice date

Most of our data points are fully complete. However we are missing some item descriptions, quite a few (25%) of our customer ID’s. These two are not able to be imputed, and we can chalk up to data quality issues. There isn’t much that we can do to remedy this. Notice too, that we don’t have a total value of individual purchases, or a total dollar value of each invoice. These are important factors to consider. We can pretty simply create these variables. Let’s also add in some date variables that we may want to look at. Finally, when we look at our quantity tab, we see that the lowest value is -80995. Without being to verify, we must assume that this means that stock was returned to the store. It could be a data quality issue, but we have no way of knowing.

Now that we have looked at our data, it is time to add in some extra variables that will help in our analysis. We will create a new data frame and call it sales.

sales <- online_retail %>%
  mutate(item_value = unit_price*quantity) %>% 
  group_by(invoice_no) %>% 
  mutate(invoice_total_value = sum(item_value)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(date = date(invoice_date), #adds in the full date, strips time
         month = month(invoice_date), ## adds invoice month
         day = day(invoice_date), ## adds invoice day in month (1-31)
         weekday = wday(invoice_date), ## adds invoice weekday (1-7) need to find if they start week on monday or sunday
         hour = hour(invoice_date)) %>%  ## adds invoice hour
    ungroup() %>%
    filter(!str_detect(description, "^[:lower:]+$"))## Found a bunch of item descriptions that seemed to be one off descriptions like "damaged", "broken" etc.. This function removes those from the data set.

skimr::skim(sales)
Table 2: Data summary
Name sales
Number of rows 540118
Number of columns 15
_______________________
Column type frequency:
Date 1
factor 4
numeric 9
POSIXct 1
________________________
Group variables None

Variable type: Date

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate min max median n_unique
date 0 1 2010-12-01 2011-12-09 2011-07-20 305

Variable type: factor

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate ordered n_unique top_counts
invoice_no 0 1 FALSE 24109 573: 1114, 581: 749, 581: 731, 580: 721
stock_code 0 1 FALSE 3954 851: 2313, 224: 2200, 850: 2159, 475: 1727
description 0 1 FALSE 4186 WHI: 2369, REG: 2200, JUM: 2159, PAR: 1727
country 0 1 FALSE 38 Uni: 493687, Ger: 9495, Fra: 8557, EIR: 8196

Variable type: numeric

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate mean sd p0 p25 p50 p75 p100 hist
quantity 0 1.00 9.64 218.00 -80995.00 1.00 3.00 10.00 80995.0 ▁▁▇▁▁
unit_price 0 1.00 4.63 96.92 -11062.06 1.25 2.08 4.13 38970.0 ▁▇▁▁▁
customer_id 133289 0.75 15287.69 1713.60 12346.00 13953.00 15152.00 16791.00 18287.0 ▇▇▇▇▇
item_value 0 1.00 18.05 379.44 -168469.60 3.48 9.84 17.40 168469.6 ▁▁▇▁▁
invoice_total_value 0 1.00 1343.76 2372.20 -168469.60 288.99 517.05 1436.93 168469.6 ▁▁▇▁▁
month 0 1.00 7.56 3.51 1.00 5.00 8.00 11.00 12.0 ▃▂▃▃▇
day 0 1.00 15.02 8.66 1.00 7.00 15.00 22.00 31.0 ▇▆▆▆▅
weekday 0 1.00 3.60 1.61 1.00 2.00 4.00 5.00 6.0 ▇▅▅▅▅
hour 0 1.00 13.08 2.44 6.00 11.00 13.00 15.00 20.0 ▁▅▇▆▁

Variable type: POSIXct

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate min max median n_unique
invoice_date 0 1 2010-12-01 08:26:00 2011-12-09 12:50:00 2011-07-20 11:22:00 22050

Looking at our new data frame, we have a lot more data to work with. We can now organize our data in so many different ways, such as hour of day, or day of the week. Speaking of day of the week, It looks like we only have sales day for day 6. Meaning that sales are not processed one day out of the week. We need to know whether Sunday or Monday equates to day 1 of 7.

sales %>% 
  filter(date == "2010-12-01") %>% 
  select(date, weekday)
## # A tibble: 3,098 x 2
##    date       weekday
##    <date>       <dbl>
##  1 2010-12-01       4
##  2 2010-12-01       4
##  3 2010-12-01       4
##  4 2010-12-01       4
##  5 2010-12-01       4
##  6 2010-12-01       4
##  7 2010-12-01       4
##  8 2010-12-01       4
##  9 2010-12-01       4
## 10 2010-12-01       4
## # ... with 3,088 more rows

Going back in the calendar, we know that December 1st 2020, starts on a Wednesday. This means that our week starts on Sunday, and by extension, that our store does not process sales on Saturday.

With our data in a more usable format, and some extra variables added, we can start our exploratory data analysis.

Exploratory Data Analysis

Sales Over Time

First and foremost, let’s look at the sales over the year. Let’s see if anything stands out right off the top before we get into the nitty gritty.

sales %>% 
  group_by(date) %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(invoice_total_value)) %>% 
  mutate(flag = ifelse(total >= 8000000, T, F)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(date, total)) +
  geom_col(aes(fill = flag)) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::dollar_format()) + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c('#595959', 'red'))+
  scale_x_date(date_breaks = "months" , date_labels = "%b-%y")+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(text = element_text(family = "Nunito Bold", face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "none",
    panel.grid.major.x  = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank()
  )+
  labs(
    title = "Total Sales by Date",
    x = "",
    y = ""
  )

We’re looking at a graph of total sales over the year. We’ve highlighted total sales per day over $8,000,000. We see a large number of these days in December in both 2010 and 2011. We can assume that December is a big month for this company. We also see a day in August that exceeded $8,000,000. Let’s take a look at that day and see if anything sticks out.

sales %>% 
  filter(month == 8) %>% 
  group_by(date) %>% 
  summarise(total = sum(invoice_total_value)) %>% 
  filter(total >= 8000000)
## # A tibble: 1 x 2
##   date          total
##   <date>        <dbl>
## 1 2011-08-11 9209482.

August 11th, 2011 had a total sales of 9.2 million. Let’s dive in and see if any orders stand out.

sales %>% 
  filter(date == "2011-08-11") %>% 
  group_by(invoice_no) %>% 
  summarize(total = sum(invoice_total_value)) %>% 
  arrange(-total) %>% 
  head(20) %>% 
  knitr::kable()
invoice_no total
562955 5887072.78
563076 2278928.54
563074 205693.84
563093 200606.56
562980 130418.40
563016 34799.80
562949 32643.02
563094 28079.52
562984 24586.05
562939 23787.36
562965 22004.40
563022 21986.85
562964 19270.80
563061 16496.20
563023 16030.20
563017 15675.52
563020 14523.36
563019 14297.28
563037 14077.50
563012 13375.53

We’ve got two invoices well over $200,000. Let’s examine those a little bit.

sales %>% 
  filter(invoice_no == 562955) %>% 
  head(5) %>% 
  select(-c(invoice_date, day, month, weekday, hour)) %>% 
  knitr::kable()
invoice_no stock_code description quantity unit_price customer_id country item_value invoice_total_value date
562955 22469 HEART OF WICKER SMALL 4 4.13 NA United Kingdom 16.52 16677.26 2011-08-11
562955 22470 HEART OF WICKER LARGE 4 5.79 NA United Kingdom 23.16 16677.26 2011-08-11
562955 22485 SET OF 2 WOODEN MARKET CRATES 3 24.96 NA United Kingdom 74.88 16677.26 2011-08-11
562955 22488 NATURAL SLATE RECTANGLE CHALKBOARD 9 3.29 NA United Kingdom 29.61 16677.26 2011-08-11
562955 22501 PICNIC BASKET WICKER LARGE 15 20.79 NA United Kingdom 311.85 16677.26 2011-08-11

Well this first order, we don’t have a customer ID. It would be worth while to find who created this invoice, so we can execute targeted marketing for future repurchases!

sales %>% 
  filter(invoice_no == 563076) %>% 
  head(5) %>% 
  select(-c(invoice_date, day, month, weekday, hour)) %>% 
  knitr::kable()
invoice_no stock_code description quantity unit_price customer_id country item_value invoice_total_value date
563076 22795 SWEETHEART RECIPE BOOK STAND 16 5.95 14646 Netherlands 95.20 19150.66 2011-08-11
563076 23176 ABC TREASURE BOOK BOX 72 1.95 14646 Netherlands 140.40 19150.66 2011-08-11
563076 22399 MAGNETS PACK OF 4 CHILDHOOD MEMORY 108 1.06 14646 Netherlands 114.48 19150.66 2011-08-11
563076 23268 SET OF 2 CERAMIC CHRISTMAS REINDEER 384 1.25 14646 Netherlands 480.00 19150.66 2011-08-11
563076 23270 SET OF 2 CERAMIC PAINTED HEARTS 192 1.25 14646 Netherlands 240.00 19150.66 2011-08-11

This is a big order out of the Netherlands that we do actually have a customer ID for. When we do our analysis on where our buying comes from, we should pay attention to the Netherlands. Perhaps this one buyer makes up a large portion of that countries total buying.

Unit Drivers

Let’s identify the largest unit drivers over the year. When we look at the data set, when we look at item descriptions with 1 or 2 units, they seem to be either 1 off or just data entry errors. We could process these out, but for the sake of this exercise, I’m going to filter to items that have a total unit value of at least 3.

unit_drivers <- sales %>% 
  select(description, quantity) %>% 
  group_by(description) %>% 
  summarise(total_quantity = sum(quantity)) %>% 
  filter(total_quantity >3) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  arrange(desc(total_quantity)) %>% 
  head(20)


unit_drivers %>% 
  ggplot(aes(fct_reorder(description, total_quantity), total_quantity, label = total_quantity)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "#303844")+
  geom_text(hjust = 1.1, color = "white",fontface = "bold")+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(text = element_text(family = "Nunito Bold", face = "bold"),
          axis.ticks = element_blank(),
          panel.grid = element_blank()
          )+
  labs(
    title = "Unit Drivers",
    subtitle = "For Calendar Year 2011",
    x = "",
    y = "Units"
  ) -> graph_unit_drivers

graph_unit_drivers

We now have a graph of our top 20 unit drivers for the year 2011. If we can find inefficiencies in our sales process for these units, we can correct for them and increase our sales revenue due to the sheer volume of sales that these units produce.

Dollar Drivers

Let’s run the same type of analysis and identify our top dollar drivers.

dollar_drivers <- sales %>% 
  select(description, invoice_total_value) %>% 
  group_by(description) %>% 
  summarise(total_dollars = sum(invoice_total_value)) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  mutate(label_text = paste("$",round(total_dollars, digits = 2)),
         label_text = trimws(label_text))%>% 
  arrange(desc(total_dollars))%>% 
  head(20)

dollar_drivers %>% 
  ggplot(aes(fct_reorder(description, total_dollars), total_dollars, label = label_text)) + 
  geom_col(fill = "#303844")+
  geom_text(hjust = 1.1, color = "white",fontface = "bold")+
  scale_y_continuous(labels=scales::dollar_format())+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(text = element_text(family = "Nunito Bold", face = "bold"),
          axis.ticks = element_blank(),
          panel.grid = element_blank()
          )+
  labs(
    title = "Dollar Drivers",
    subtitle = "For Calendar Year 2011",
    x = "",
    y = ""
  ) -> graph_dollar_drivers

graph_dollar_drivers

Looking at the two graphs we can see that a few SKU’s show up in both the dollar drivers and the unit drivers. For instance the Party Bunting, and the Pack of 72 Retrospot Cake Cases. It is safe to say that these two SKU’s make up an important part of the business.

Where in the World Are Our Sales?

sales_by_country <- sales %>% 
  select(country, invoice_total_value) %>%
  group_by(country) %>% 
  summarise(total_sales_by_country = sum(invoice_total_value)) 


sales_by_country %>% 
  arrange(desc(total_sales_by_country)) %>% 
  gt() %>% 
  fmt_currency(
    # Define the columns to change
    columns = vars(total_sales_by_country),
    # How many decimals to round to
    decimals = 2,
  ) %>%
  # Align the now character column to be right-aligned
  cols_align(
    align = "right",
    columns = vars(total_sales_by_country)) %>% 
  cols_label(
    total_sales_by_country = "Total Sales",
    country = "Country"
  )  %>%
  tab_header(
    title = md("**Sales by Country**"),
    subtitle = "2011"
  )

The vast, vast majority of the yearly sales came from the UK. Considering that this business is based there, that makes sense. Looking at our lowest value countries, We have Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and The Czech Republic. If there is marketing dollars being spent there currently, it may be wise to move it else where.

Wrap Up

We took a look at our sales data from this anonymized store data set. We look at unit drivers, dollar drivers and which countries produced the most sales. In the future it would be beneficial to examine customer segmentation, perhaps utilizing KNN. I will save that for a future blog post however.
